nodes.text: The Almost Ideal Demand System (AIDS) provides a flexible, theoretically consistent, and practically estimable demand system superior to existing flexible forms for testing and extending conventional demand analysis

AIDS is derived from a PIGLOG class cost function log c(u,p) = (1-u) log a(p) + u log b(p) with specific flexible forms for log a(p) and log b(p) producing a cost function that is linearly homogeneous in prices

The AIDS budget-share demand equations are wi = ai + sum_j yij log pj + beta_i log(x/P) where P is a price index defined from the cost function, and parameters satisfy linear adding-up, homogeneity, and symmetry restrictions when derived from utility maximization

AIDS is a flexible functional form providing a first-order (local) approximation to any demand system: its parameters can match derivatives of arbitrary true demand functions at a point even without assuming utility maximization

AIDS permits exact aggregation over heterogeneous households under PIGLOG/PIGL assumptions by introducing household scale parameters kh and an aggregate index k, so aggregate budget shares correspond to a representative consumer with budget x/k

Estimation can be simplified in practice by approximating the theoretical price index P with Stone's price index P* = exp(sum w_k log p_k), allowing single-equation OLS estimation equation-by-equation and iterative reweighting

Restrictions for theory-consistency: adding-up (sum ai =1), homogeneity (sum_j yij =0 for each i), and Slutsky symmetry (yij = yji); negativity (concavity) cannot be ensured by linear parameter restrictions and must be checked via eigenvalues of the Slutsky matrix
Derivation property: price derivatives of the AIDS cost function yield quantities (Shephard's lemma) and logarithmic differentiation of log c(u,p) gives the budget-share form used for estimation
Specific parameterization of log a(p) and log b(p) includes linear homogeneity and enough parameters to be a flexible form, with normalization choices to handle ordinal utility

AIDS parameters have economic interpretation: yij approximate compensated cross-price effects, beta_i indicate expenditure responses (positive for luxuries, negative for necessities), and ai, bi represent poverty and affluence expenditure patterns

AIDS relates to other models: in first-difference form its right-hand side resembles the Rotterdam model, and under special restrictions the translog indirect utility can be represented within the PIGLOG/AIDS framework

Because the AIDS is flexible, many parameters may be poorly identified in typical data; empirical practice requires imposing plausible restrictions (e.g., zeroing some yij) or using approximations to reduce estimation uncertainty

Interpretation of aggregation index k: k summarizes distributional and demographic structure (reduces to Theil entropy/H when tastes identical); omitting k is acceptable if k is constant or uncorrelated with prices and mean expenditure, otherwise omitted variable bias may arise

Empirical application: estimating AIDS on UK annual data 1954-1974 for eight nondurable categories using P* approximation, OLS single-equation estimation followed by system reestimation and likelihood-based tests

Empirical results (levels): homogeneity and especially symmetry are decisively rejected in levels; many yij are significant; food and housing classified as necessities; overall price inelasticity except transport and communication

Imposing homogeneity often generates positive serial correlation in residuals of the equations that most strongly reject homogeneity, suggesting omitted dynamics, stock effects, time trends, or price expectation issues

First-difference estimation reduces rejections of homogeneity and makes symmetry less decisively rejected, indicating that allowing for time trends or dynamics brings data closer to the representative-consumer static model; however concavity violations persist in estimates
